[[File:Tahrir Square attacks on April 9 2011.png|thumb|A protester holding army bullets, standing in front of an army vehicle that was burned during the massive army attack on April 9, 2011 in Tahrir Square, where at least two protesters were killed and tens wounded by the Egyptian army.]]
'''[[Human rights]] in the [[Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|post-Mubarak transition]]''' have been the subject of concern and controversy since the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]]. The '''[[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] (SCAF)''' ({{lang-ar|Ø§ÙÙ Ø¬ÙØ³ Ø§ÙØ£Ø¹ÙÙ ÙÙÙÙØ§Øª Ø§ÙÙ Ø³ÙØ­Ø©}}, ''{{transl|ar|DIN|al-MaÇ§lis al-Ê¾AÊ¿lÄ lil-QuwwÄt al-Musallaá¸¥ah}}'' in particular have been the focus of [[Human rights violations|concerns about human rights violations]]. The SCAF, which consists of a body of 20<ref name="sis">{{cite web| url=http://www.sis.gov.eg/En/LastPage.aspx?Category_ID=1136| author=Egypt State Information Service| title=Formation of the Armed Forces Supreme Council.| date=14 February 2011}} Archived at webcite at http://www.webcitation.org/5wTMNq7Mb</ref> senior officers in the [[Egyptian Armed Forces|Egyptian military]], was handed the power to govern [[Egypt]] after the ouster of [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]] on 11 February 2011<ref name="globe">{{cite news |url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/crisis-in-egypt/the-new-face-of-power-in-cairo/article1904700/ |author=The Globe and Mail |title=The New Face of Power in Egypt. |date=11 February 2011| accessdate=11 February 2011 |location=Toronto}}</ref><ref name="wt">{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/feb/11/crowds-rejoice-egypts-mubarak-steps-down/ |author=Murdock, Heather |title=Crowds rejoice as Egyptâs Mubarak steps down, hands power to military| publisher=[[The Washington Times]]| date=11 February 2011| accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> as a consequence of the revolution.
==Torture== [[File:Ramy Essam.jpg|thumb|Ramy Essam]] Ramy Essam, a 23-year-old Egyptian student and musician, was arrest and tortured by the army police on 9 March 2011.<ref name="CNN">{{cite news|author=By Â Reza Sayah, CNN |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/03/17/egypt.activists/index.html |title=Pro-democracy activists allege torture by Egyptian soldiers - CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date=18 March 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref> He was one of more than 100 people arrested when the army, without warning, stormed the [[Tahrir Square|square]], ripping down tents.<ref name="NPR"/> Essam says men in army uniforms dragged him to the Egyptian National Museum, which had become a security headquarters,<ref name="NPR"/> and took him to a courtyard, stripped him to his shorts, and started torturing him.<ref name="NPR"/> "They used sticks, metal rods, wires, whips." He said he also received electric shocks.<ref name="CNN"/> "There was a soldier who would jump in the air and land on my face with his legs".<ref name="CNN"/> Ramy Essam is best known as "the singer of the Egyptian revolution" due to his popular music during the Egyptian uprising against Hosni Mubarak.<ref name="NPR">{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/2011/03/15/134538629/ramy-esam-the-singer-of-the-egyptian-revolution |title=Ramy Essam: The Singer Of The Egyptian Revolution |publisher=NPR |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref>
==Virginity testing== {{see|Virginity test}} {{External media | video1 = {{YouTube|NuR8gIYMEY8|Egyptian army denies 'virginity tests'}} | video2 = {{YouTube|ajCe1km7UFM|Salwa's testimony, who was arrested by the army on March 9, 2011}} }} {{Expand section|date=July 2011}} Since the overthrow of Mubarak there have been widespread reports of detained Egyptian women having their "virginity checked" by a male officer or doctor. Numerous journalists and released prisoners and protesters have confirmed the practice, by which Egyptian officers were said to evaluate whether or not these women had been raped.<ref>{{cite news|last=Leyne |first=Jon |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13796966 |title=BBC News - Egypt's defiant women fear being cast aside |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= 19 June 2011|accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=June 2, 2011 |  9:32 am |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/06/egypt-victim-details-virginity-test-denies-military-claims.html |title=EGYPT: Woman denies military's claims about 'virginity test' - latimes.com |publisher=Latimesblogs.latimes.com |date=2011-06-02 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/may/31/briefing-page-mideast/ |title=Briefly: Mideast |publisher=Washington Times |date=2011-05-31 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Backchannels/2011/0601/Virginity-tests-Misogyny-and-intimidation-in-Egypt |title=Virginity tests: Misogyny and intimidation in Egypt |publisher=CSMonitor.com |date=2011-06-01 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NuR8gIYMEY8 |title=âªEgyptian army denies 'virginity tests'â¬â |publisher=YouTube |date=2011-06-01 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,767365,00.html |title='Horribly Humiliating': Egyptian Woman Tells of 'Virginity Tests' - SPIEGEL ONLINE - News - International |publisher=Spiegel.de |date= |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref> The Egyptian military initially denied any virginity checks taking place<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/06/20116255012877754.html |title=Egyptian army denies 'virginity tests' - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2011-06-02 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref> and then asserted the practice would not continue in the future.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://old.news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20110607/wl_africa_afp/egyptpoliticsunrestrights_20110607172638 |title=Egypt military rulers vow no more virginity tests: HRW - Yahoo! News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=(AFP) – Jun 7, 2011 |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5h1oml-bY_PJl5W9cPJtbpdUY_y-Q?docId=CNG.fafcacea0287fbeab90256732f165e1e.3a1 |title=AFP: Egypt military rulers vow no more virginity tests: HRW |publisher=Google.com |date=2011-06-07 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref> News of the virginity tests sparked a public outcry from [[Amnesty International]] and [[Human Rights Watch]] as well as local Egyptian activists, [[Mona Seif]] for example, and other citizens in the country.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-20067419-503543.html |title=Report: Egypt admits to forcing "virginity tests" - World Watch |publisher=CBS News |date= |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=10729592 |title=Egyptian activists voice outrage at 'virginity tests' - World - NZ Herald News |publisher=Nzherald.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.cfr.org/coleman/2011/06/03/what-do-egyptians-say-about-the-militarys-virginity-testing/ |title=Isobel Coleman: Democracy in Development Â» Blog Archive Â» What Do Egyptians Say about the Militaryâs âVirginity Testingâ? |publisher=Blogs.cfr.org |date=2011-06-03 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Mackey |first=Robert |url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/06/01/egyptian-bloggers-press-army-on-abuses-during-interim-rule/ |title=Egyptian Bloggers Press Army on Abuses During Interim Rule - NYTimes.com |location=Egypt |publisher=Thelede.blogs.nytimes.com |date=2011-06-01 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref> Protesters see the tests as evidence that more reform is needed and that the rule under SCAF is neither stable nor trustworthy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/465795 |title=Rights groups says Egypt still needs more change | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2011-06-01 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/worldwide/middle-east/disillusion-starts-to-grow-with-egypts-military-amid-fears-of-mini-mubaraks?pageCount=0 |title=Disillusion starts to grow with Egypt's military amid fears of 'mini-Mubaraks - The National |publisher=Thenational.ae |date= |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/466660 |title=Human Rights Watch: The Egyptian revolution is not over | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2010-01-24 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref>
==Military trials== {{multiple image | width1 = 150 | width2 = 225 | align = | footer = Amr El Beheiry and some of the 9th of March detainees | image1 = Amr El beheiry.jpg | image2 = Some of the 9th of March detainees (Egypt).jpg }}
At the Israeli Embassy in Cairo on 15 May, [[2011 Nakba Day|thousands gathered for a pro-Palestinian demonstration]] but were dispersed by Egyptian security and the army police forces with tear gas and live ammunition.<ref name="Bikya">{{cite web|url=http://bikyamasr.com/wordpress/?p=33601 |title=Army fires on Cairoâs Nakba rally |publisher=Bikyamasr.com |date=2011-05-17 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref> Some 353 protesters were injured and 180 arrested.<ref>[http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/440439 Rights organization urges release of Nakba protesters]. ''[[Al-Masry Al-Youm]]''. 17 May 2011.</ref> At least two of the wounded had been shot in head and chest by security and army police forces, and at least two of those arrested (Mosa'ab Elshamy and Tarek Shalaby) were well known for their [[Twitter|Twitter activity]] throughout the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]].<ref name=Bikya/> All those who were arrested faced military trials and were later freed.
Seven<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/egypt-cant-move-forward-without-justice-says-amnesty-sec-gen.html |title=Egypt can't move forward without justice, says Amnesty sec-gen |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref> to ten-thousand civilians<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/jun/22/egypt-army-military-tribunals |title=The Egyptian army's mask has slipped | Austin Mackell | Comment is free | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date=2008-05-29 |accessdate=2011-07-07 |location=London}}</ref> were tried in military tribunals in the period between February and June 2011, according to Human Rights Watch.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/465795 |title=Rights groups says Egypt still needs more change | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=1 June 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> One, Amr El Beheiry,<ref name="Associated">{{cite web|last=Associated |first=The |url=http://wvgazette.com/ap/ApInternational/201105270558 |title=Egypt activists plan 'Second Revolution' - AP World News - The Charleston Gazette - West Virginia News and Sports |publisher=Wvgazette.com |date=27 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> was arrested during a violent military dispersal of a sit-in at the parliament on 26 February.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/may/27/world/la-fg-egypt-prisoners-20110527 |title=Egypt democracy protests: Egyptian activists plan protests over military trials - Los Angeles Times |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=27 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011 |first=Molly |last=Hennessy-Fiske}}</ref> He was then referred to military court and after a swift trial without the presence of an attorney,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/451026 |title=Activists continue their battle against military trials as SCAF releases detainees | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=25 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> and received a sentence of five years on thuggery charges despite the testimonies of many eyewitnesses who said he broke no laws.<ref>{{cite web|author=Evan Hill |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/05/2011519172611166398.html |title=Egypt's crackdown now wears camouflage - Features |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=20 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> Amnesty International also has called for Beheiry's release.<ref name="Associated"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/05/19/egypt-human-rights-abuse-_n_864027.html |title=Egypt Human Rights Abuse Continues: Amnesty |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-30}}</ref>
Another activist that has been detained is Loai Nagati.<ref name="ahram3">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/15393/Egypt/Politics-/Loai-Nagati-another-Egyptian-activist-to-face-mili.aspx |title=Loai Nagati: another Egyptian activist to face military trial - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-07-01}}</ref> The [[We are all Khaled Said|We Are All Khaled Said]] Facebook page said: "Loai Nagati is a 21 years old Egyptian Activist who got arrested during Tahrir protests yesterday morning. As it has become the norm now, Loai has been sent to 15 days in a military jail awaiting a military investigation! Loai didnât have a lawyer, has no clear accusation against him & is a computer science student. He is a civilian & shouldnât be investigated by military prosecuters. End military trials of civilians in Egypt NOW! 45 protesters have been arrested so far during Tahrir protests on 28 June night & 29 June morning. All sent to military trials."<ref>{{cite web|title=Loai Nagati is a 21 years old Egyptian Activist|url=http://liveword.ca/egypt/2011/06/30/24076/|publisher=http://liveword.ca/|accessdate=2 July 2011}}</ref> An active Tweeter, Nagati was Tweeting (@LoaiNagati) from Tahrir Square about what was taking place when he was arrested. âSeveral people are injured,â was the last tweet by Nagati at 7am on Wednesday.<ref name="ahram3"/> Nagati is to be detained for 15 days and was transferred on June 29 to military prison pending a military trial.<ref name="elbadil1">{{cite news|title=Ø´ÙÙÙ ÙØ¤Ù ÙØ¬Ø§ØªÙ Ù Ø¹ØªÙÙ Ø§ÙØ³Ø¬Ù Ø§ÙØ­Ø±Ø¨Ù Ø§ÙÙ Ø±ÙØ¶ Ø¨Ø§ÙÙÙØ¨: Ù ÙØ¹ÙÙÙ Ù Ù Ø¥Ø¯Ø®Ø§Ù Ø£Ø¯ÙÙØ© ÙÙ ÙØ·Ø§ÙØ¨ØªÙÙ Ø¨Ø§ÙÙØ¨Ø¶ Ø¹ÙÙ ÙØ£Ø¯Ø®Ù Ø§ÙØ¯ÙØ§Ø¡|url=http://elbadil.net/%D8%B4%D9%82%D9%8A%D9%82-%D9%84%D8%A4%D9%8A-%D9%86%D8%AC%D8%A7%D8%AA%D9%8A-%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%AA%D9%82%D9%84-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B3%D8%AC%D9%86-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AD%D8%B1%D8%A8%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B1/|accessdate=2 July 2011|newspaper=http://elbadil.net/|date=1 July 2011}}</ref> Nagati has a heart condition as well as digestive problems which require 10 different medications, and after some struggle, an officer who works at the prison agreed to the transfer of the medication to Nagati.<ref name="elbadil1"/>
[[Asmaa Mahfouz]] was arrested on charges of defaming the [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|Egyptian military junta]] for calling them a "council of dogs". She was referred to a military court, prompting activists, as well as presidential hopefuls such as [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] and [[Ayman Nour]], to protest her being charged in a military court.<ref>Osman, Ahmed Zaki [http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/486440 Activists and presidential hopefuls condemn Asmaa Mahfouz arrest] al-Masry al-Youm. 15 August 2011</ref> Mahfouz was released on bail in the amount of 20,000 Egyptian Pounds, equivalent to approximately 3,350 US dollars.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14524094 Egypt blogger Mahfuz quizzed for 'defaming' military] BBC News. 14 August 2011</ref><ref>Osman, Ahmed Zaki [http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/486305 Activist released from military court on LE20,000 bail for Facebook post] al-Masry al-Youm. 14 August 2011</ref>
==Censorship== [[File:Ganzeer.jpg|thumb|Mohammed Fahmy AKA Ganzeer, the graffiti artist who designed the sticker<ref name="twitpic1">{{cite web|url=http://twitpic.com/52p7n6 |title=#FreeGanzeer - Hi Res Poster That Ganzeer Got Arrested for. on Twitpic |publisher=Twitpic.com |date=2011-05-26 |accessdate=2011-08-06}}</ref> on the t-shirt and got arrested for posting it in [[Tahrir Square]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0526/Egyptian-graffiti-artist-Ganzeer-arrested-amid-surge-in-political-expression |title=Egyptian graffiti artist Ganzeer arrested amid surge in political expression |publisher=CSMonitor.com |date=26 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref>]]
Graffiti artist Ganzeer, film director Aida El-Kashef, and musician/painter Nadim Amin AKA NadimX were arrested<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/5/35/13024/Arts--Culture/Stage--Street/CIC-condemns-arrest-of-artists-by-military-.aspx |title=CIC condemns arrest of artists by military - Stage & Street - Arts & Culture - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=26 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> for posting a poster<ref name="twitpic1"/> that offended the military police. They were released later that day.<ref>{{cite web|author=New York Times, USA |url=http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/27/egypt-gearing-up-for-a-second-revolutionary-round/ |title=Egypt: Gearing Up for a Second Revolutionary Round Â· Global Voices |publisher=Globalvoicesonline.org |date=27 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> "I donât know why we were transferred to the military prosecution" said graffiti artist Mohamed Fahmy, a 29-year-old Egyptian artist,<ref>{{cite news|author=Jack Shenker in Cairo |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/may/19/egypts-uprising-diy-art-cairo-streets |title=Egypt's uprising brings DIY spirit out on to the streets | World news |publisher=The Guardian |date= 19 May 2011|accessdate=13 June 2011 |location=London}}</ref> who goes by Ganzeer on Twitter, minutes after his release. He said that in custody he and others talked about "politics and democracy".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/graffiti-artist-says-online-outcry-may-have-sped-up-release.html |title=Graffiti artist says online outcry may have sped up release |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/05/26/egypts-youth-vocal-against-army |title=Egypt's youth vocal against army | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=26 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref>
Another activist who was detained after Mubarak's ousting was Maikel Nabil Sanad,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maikelnabil.com/2010/12/my-cv.html |title=Maikel Nabil Sanad Ù Ø§ÙÙÙ ÙØ¨ÙÙ Ø³ÙØ¯: About me |publisher=Maikelnabil.com |date=2010-12-05 |accessdate=2011-08-14}}</ref> a political activist and blogger. In April 2009 he founded the No to Compulsory Military Service movement. He declared his [[conscientious objection]], demanding to be exempted from military service. Instead, he was arrested on 12 November 2010 by military police but was released two days later, and finally exempted from service on medical grounds. Sanad participated actively in the Egyptian revolution, highlighting the fact that Egypt has effectively been ruled by the military for six decades. He was arrested on 4 February by military police and tortured, but released 27 hours later. He was arrested in his home in the Ain Shams neighbourhood in Cairo at about 10 PM on 28 March 2011 by military police. He was only able to call his brother the next day to inform him of his arrest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wri-irg.org/node/12513 |title=EGYPT: Egyptian pacifist Maikel Nabil Sanad arrested for insulting the military | War Resisters' International |publisher=Wri-irg.org |date= |accessdate=2011-08-14}}</ref> Sanad was sentenced to three years' imprisonment on charges of "insulting the military" in his post "The Army and The People Were Never One Hand" on maikelnabil.com<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maikelnabil.com/2011/03/army-and-people-wasnt-ever-one-hand.html |title=Maikel Nabil Sanad Ù Ø§ÙÙÙ ÙØ¨ÙÙ Ø³ÙØ¯: The Army and The People Were Never One Hand |publisher=Maikelnabil.com |date=2011-03-08 |accessdate=2011-08-14}}</ref> by the 10th of Ramadan military court in Nasr City near Cairo on 10 April. Before this, he was imprisoned in a special punishment cell at El Marg prison, which did not allow him any sunlight. In addition, his cell mates threatened him. Sanad demanded a doctor, as he suffers from unstable blood pressure and needs regular medication and medical attention.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wri-irg.org/node/13004 |title=EGYPT: Imprisoned pacifist blogger Maikel Nabil Sanad in solitary confinement | War Resisters' International |publisher=Wri-irg.org |date= |accessdate=2011-08-14}}</ref>
Egyptian blogger and activist [[Hossam el-Hamalawy]], television host [[Reem Maged]] and journalist [[Nabil Sharaf El-Din]] were given a summons on 30 May 2011 to appear before military prosecution after Maged brought Hamalawy on her show where he criticized the role of the military police, holding the head of the military police responsible for torturing activists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/13270/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptian-journalists-to-be-questioned-tomorrow-by-.aspx |title=Egyptian journalists to be questioned tomorrow by military for denouncing the torture of activists - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=30 May 2011}}</ref> They were released Tuesday after "chatting" with Military Prosecution and Hossam el-Hamalawy was asked to hand in reports of army abuses to authorities.<ref name="DailyEgypt">{{cite web|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/blogger-asked-to-hand-reports-of-army-abuses-to-authorities.html |title=Blogger asked to hand reports of army abuses to authorities |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=7 June 2011}}</ref>
Egyptian journalist and activist [[Rasha Azab]] and ''[[El Fagr]]'' newspaper editor in chief [[Adel Hammouda]] have been summoned by military prosecution. They are to appear before military prosecutors on 19 June 2011.<ref name="ahram1">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/14532.aspx |title=Journalists Rasha Azab and Adel Hammouda summoned by Egypt's military prosecution - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-06-18}}</ref> Azab had published an article in ''El Fagr'' newspaper detailing the meeting that took place between members of the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces (SCAF) and the No to Military Trials campaigners.<ref name="ahram1"/>
==Deaths== [[File:Coward assault to protesters in Abbaseya Egypt.gif|thumb|Poster for Mohamed Mohsen, another victim of the SCAF, artwork by [[Carlos Latuff]]]] Ramy Fakhry,<ref name="ahram2"/> a 27-year-old electrical engineer, died as a result of bullet wounds received at an army checkpoint somewhere in the governorate of Damietta. The checkpointâs exact location is unknown.<ref name="thedailynewsegypt1">{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailynewsegypt.com/crime-a-accidents/family-of-man-killed-at-checkpoint-demands-investigation.html |title=Family of man killed at checkpoint demands investigation |publisher=www.thedailynewsegypt.com|date=2011-05-15 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}</ref> According to one, unconfirmed, version of events, Fakhry stopped his car just short of the checkpoint when he saw a gunfight between the army and assailants ahead of him and was shot three times in the back as he attempted to drive away.<ref name="thedailynewsegypt1"/> Another version of the story says he left the rig where he worked near Damietta on Friday 13 May to attend a wedding. On his way back later that night at 1 am â before the curfew imposed at the time â Fakhry was shot dead at an army checkpoint.<ref name="ahram2">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/14715/Egypt/Politics-/Activists-and-friends-seek-answers-over-Ramy-Fakhr.aspx |title=Activists and friends seek answers over Ramy Fakhryâs death|publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-06-21 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}</ref> A candlelight vigil was organized by Ramy's family and friends on May 14, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabawy.org/2011/05/17/tribute-to-ramy-fakhry-%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%85%D9%8A-%D9%81%D8%AE%D8%B1%D9%8A/ |title=Tribute to Ramy Fakhry 3|publisher=www.arabawy.org|date=2011-05-17 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}</ref> Head of the Supreme Council for Armed Force (SCAF), Field Marshal Hussein Tantawi, ordered an investigation into the killing of Ramy Fakhry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailynewsegypt.com/people/following-vigil-scaf-orders-investigation-into-army-shooting-of-engineer.html |title=Following vigil, SCAF orders investigation into army shooting of engineer |publisher=www.thedailynewsegypt.com|date=2011-05-17 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}</ref> The statement has not been followed up with any updates concerning the investigation, prompting the call for action.<ref name="ahram2"/> Whatever the circumstances activists believe that Fakhry<ref name="ahram2"/> was killed by the army.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/12289/Egypt/Politics-/Candlelight-vigil-for-Egyptian-shot-by-army-asks-W.aspx |title=Candlelight vigil for Egyptian shot by army asks 'Why was Ramy killed?' |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-05-17 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}</ref>
On August 4, Mohamed Mohsen, a protester and an activist, died at Nasser Hospital Institute, 12 days after he was hit with a rock that caused him brain hemorrhage. Mohsen had participated in a march on July 23 heading to the Ministry of Defense in denouncement of SCAF, which was stopped at the neighborhood of Abbasseya by military troops. Thereafter, the entire march was attacked by thugs, and allegedly by the residents of Abbasseya as well, who threw rocks and molotov cocktails at the protesters. One eyewitness said Mohsen was hit by a rock from a nearby rooftop, which made it likely that he was indeed hit by a resident of the area. Protesters were unable to have him hospitalized for over two hours, as ambulances couldn't reach the march, which was surrounded by military police, and he was not taken to the nearby Demerdash Hospital because of rumors that injured protesters were being arrested. After several other hospitals refused to take him in he was eventually admitted at the Nasser Hospital. The lag between his injury and hospitalization as well as apparently very poor health care eventually led to Mohsen's death.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shorouknews.com/contentdata.aspx?id=518916 |title=Ululations in farewell to the Abbasseya martyr |publisher=Shorouknews.com |language=[[Arabic]] |date= |accessdate=2011-08-06}}</ref> Protesters blamed SCAF for his death, as it was believed the attacks against the march came at the incitement and fear-mongering of the military, and specifically put the blame on Major General Hassan el-Ruweiny. A large funeral was held for him in his home city of [[Aswan]], and around 200 protesters held a funeral at a mosque near [[Tahrir Square]], after [[Friday Prayer]]s. It was blocked from entering the square by military police and [[Central Security Forces]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/483566 |title=Protesters show solidarity with victim of Abbasseya attack | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2011-07-23 |accessdate=2011-08-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dostor.org/politics/egypt/11/august/5/50278 |title=Military Police block a march to Tahrir Square |publisher=Dostor.org |language=[[Arabic]] |date= |accessdate=2011-08-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/node/483640 |title=Army and Police close Tahrir Square to Protesters for the first time after the Revolution |publisher=Almasryalyoum.com |language=[[Arabic]] |date= |accessdate=2011-08-06}}</ref> Later during the day, protesters had a Ramadan [[iftar]] in the square in a celebratory manner, but soon afterwards were attacked and dispersed by military police after claiming they were planning on renewing the sit-in in Tahrir.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/node/483685 |title=Army forces disperse the "Tahrir Iftar" |publisher=Almasryalyoum.com |language=[[Arabic]] |date= |accessdate=2011-08-06}}</ref>
